node.title: FileMesh vs. FileMeshGenerator
node.bodyText:
Can someone please explain to me the difference between FileMesh and FileMeshGenerator?
I have come across a strange situation where initial_from_file_var works fine if I use FileMesh, but does not work if I use FileMeshGenerator. I don't get an error, but the variables are not being initialised when I use FileMeshGenerator to read the mesh.

FileMeshGenerator is the preferred way for creating meshes. It is part of the new mesh generation system. FileMesh could be deprecated in the future if I understand correctly. To make initial_from_file_var work with FileMeshGenerator, you will need to set this parameter use_for_exodus_restart to true in the mesh generator to tell MOOSE that this exodus file can be used for initializing variables later.

All this really needs to be documented!
The doc string "True to indicate that the mesh file this generator is reading can be used for restarting variables" seems to say nothing about initializing variables, only "restarting" them.
Ideally, there should be a link to a test/example that shows users how to initialize variables.
Also, this documentation is really hard to understand "users can use parameter exodus_extra_element_integers to load elemental variables for setting extra element integers of the mesh. The names of the extra element integers will be the same as the names of the element variables in the mesh file" .   Another example would be useful.
Agree the doco could be a bit more clear!
I've been wondering for a while why the old mesh generation methods haven't been deprecated.

I don't get an error, but the variables are not being initialised when I use FileMeshGenerator to read the mesh.

Forgot replying this part: You should hit an error message saying you are missing use_for_exodus_restart.
For example, in moose/test/tests/ics/from_exodus_solution/elem_part2.i if you comment out that parameter, you will hit an error.

Thanks @YaqiWang, it turns out I last updated MOOSE 2 days before you added that bit to the code! Note to self, must update more often :-) Then I would have got the error message and saved myself some hassle.
You are welcome. This code was added by me ;-) Doc is always difficult especially we do not have end users as reviewers.

node.title: How to perform distributed-mesh computation?
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE experts
I am trying to modify a 2D porous media hydromechanical problem to 3D.  In 3D, the model generates the mesh using CartesianMeshGenerator and has less than 150 M elements. A direct run (e.g., mpiexec -n 50) is always out of memory.
I have tried to split the mesh into 50 chunks by running:
mpiexec -n 50 ./porous_flow-opt -i test.i --split-mesh 50

Then run by
mpiexec -n 50 ./porous_flow-opt -i test.i --use-split

However, the memory-out problem remains. The problem file is here (github link ).
I am working on a university cluster. Each node has 56 cpus and a shared memory about 170 G.
Perhaps something wrong with my MOOSE installation?
The run_test log can be seen here (github link)
Could someone give some solutions? Thanks!

You don’t need that many processes for the initial split. When splitting the mesh, just a few procs is sufficient. Give something like 5 a try.
Keep in mind that during the splitting, if the mesh is replicated it must be loaded on each proc. In general terms, this means you could be effectively loading (150 million x 50 procs) elements! Instead, with 5 processors the mesh is duplicated only 5 times.
Are you running out of memory splitting the mesh or running with the split mesh?

Are you running out of memory splitting the mesh or running with the split mesh?
The latter. There is no problem when splitting the mesh. I will soon try usingless procs. Thank you.
When you run the latter problem, do you get to the point where the framework prints out its information (version, number of elements, variables, etc)? If so, paste that here.

Initializing equation system                                                               [  1.82 s]
Framework Information:
MOOSE Version:           git commit dfbdf0e on 2020-12-02
LibMesh Version:         0d19e76fc8e7345a0634cba450f488b3a5626eb3
PETSc Version:           3.13.3
SLEPc Version:           3.13.3
Current Time:            Wed Mar  3 23:34:35 2021
Executable Timestamp:    Tue Dec  8 09:28:56 2020
Parallelism:
Num Processors:          50
Num Threads:             1
Mesh:
Parallel Type:           distributed (pre-split)
Mesh Dimension:          3
Spatial Dimension:       3
Nodes:
Total:                 1521194
Local:                 33277
Elems:
Total:                 1480800
Local:                 29621
Num Subdomains:          2
Num Partitions:          1
Partitioner:             parmetis
Nonlinear System:
Num DOFs:                6084776
Num Local DOFs:          133108
Variables:               { "pwater" "disp_x" "disp_y" "disp_z" }
Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE"
Approximation Orders:    "FIRST"
Auxiliary System:
Num DOFs:                60712800
Num Local DOFs:          1214461
Variables:               { "stress_xx" "stress_zz" "stress_yy" "strain_yy" "strain_yy_0" "strain_yy_2"
"strain_xx" "strain_zz" "perm_md" "perm" } "PorousFlow_effective_fluid_pressure_qp"
Finite Element Types:    "MONOMIAL" "MONOMIAL"
Approximation Orders:    "FIRST" "CONSTANT"
Execution Information:
Executioner:             Steady
Solver Mode:             NEWTON
PETSc Preconditioner:    lu
MOOSE Preconditioner:    SMP
Outputting exodus .................Warning:  This MeshOutput subclass only supports meshes which have been serialized!
Warning:  This MeshOutput subclass only supports meshes which have been serialized!
...Warning, Exodus files cannot have titles longer than 80 characters.  Your title will be truncated.
.........                                            [ 30.31 s]
Computing initial residual ...                                                             [  4.46 s]
Updating displaced mesh                                                                    [  1.69 s]
0 Nonlinear |R| = 5.964885e+08
Updating displaced mesh                                                                    [  1.71 s]
Then after several mins the system stopped the run. I received the information with "Memory size limit exceeded" from the cluster.

Depending on how big your mesh is, you may also need to switch your output to Nemesis (DistributedMesh output analog), otherwise you will end up serializing the mesh to the root processor for output, which could still run you out of memory.
[Outputs]
 ...
 nemesis = true
 exodus = false
[]
Thank you for this suggestion. This partially solves the problem.

I would hazard a guess that it is your use of LU+MUMPS.  Although that might work for smaller meshes, you might be forced to try ASM+LU+MUMPS, or HYPRE+BOOMERAMG, or ILU, or something else - i'm sure lots of other people can suggest other things to try.
If this is the case, then.... when you try different solver choices, i strongly suggest you do it on a smaller problem, so you get more rapid feedback on whether you have made a good choice (pay attention to the rate of convergence of the linear and the nonlinear residual, and feel free to ask for more help if you're not entirely sure).  i recommended MUMPS in the PorousFlow doco because it is a "generally good" choice (works for most models) but there are plenty of models which behave very satisfactorily with a "weaker", less memory-intensive option.
a

Andy, many thanks. Yes, the suggestion helps.  This 3D problem is essentially the same as the previously posted 2D problem. After your suggestion, I have taken some time on testing the setting of the solver and preconditioner.
Basically, I find
 petsc_options_value = 'bcgs bjacobi'


or
 petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'

can reduce the residual.
Now the problem is the low solver efficiency.

node.title: [XFEM][Moving interface]
node.bodyText:
Dear Users,
I have studied the moving interface in the XFEM app.
But I got some problems with domain.
I want to simulate an expansion of domain (block) and assign material properties in the expanded domain.
But it seems like there is no way to apply material properties to the expanded domain.
More precisely, how can I apply a moving interface between two different domains?
One domain will expand, and the other will be shrunk...
Until now, I could see examples for a single domain.
Best regards,
Nakkyu

I have read the following post.
#16008
Is it possible to use "ActivateElementUserObject" to change elements domain id from one to another?
If possible, I think I can use it to solve my problem.
Best regards,
Nakkyu
@jiangwen84 Can you help out here?
@aeslaughter Do you want to review the PR #17101 which (together with another follow-up PR) does exactly this? @coskrrb2002 hopefully we can add this capability soon...

Thank you.
This is what I want to use for my modeling.
I guess I have to wait.
@coskrrb2002  Could you let us what physical problem you are trying to solve?

I am trying to solve corrosion of metals in solution with oxide film formation.
So, that's why I need a domain growth and shrink~.
And I found the way to do this in moose just today.
So, I am applying it my model and waiting a result.

node.title: Error: Can't output Elems with invalid ids!
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE users,
My model has Phase Field+ Tensor mechanics kernels and I am using the combined module.
When my Tensor mechanic is Elastic ( elastic stress and strain) I have no problem.
But, when I add plasticity to my model , I get this error of "Can't output Elems with invalid ids!" after some steps.
What I figured out so far is that it is some how related to the adaptive mesh I have. For example, if I chose to update my mesh every 6 iterations, the error occurs around t = 5e-6 sec. But, if I update every 18 iterations it lasts up to  t = 5e-4 sec.
I would appreciate any help on this matter.
I have attached some part of my input file.
plastic_github.txt
P.S. My MOOSE version is kinda old!
@sapitts Have you seen this before with Tensor Mechanics?

I have not seen this error before, but based on some discussions I've had with @laagesen and @dschwen I believe there is an issue with plasticity stateful materials and mesh adaptivity: we don't currently have the infrastructure to handle moving over stateful properties (e.g. the old plastic state from the previous timestep) to a modified mesh. Daniel or Larry, would one of you be willing to clarify/ expand on this issue please?
It could be that you see the difference in the "allowable" simulation time is a function of both the onset of plasticity and how close to that onset the mesh is modified through adaptivity. I suspect that as soon as the simulation goes to look for the old plastic state material property information on a mesh that has been modified by adaptivity. If you delay adaptivity, the simulation should be able to run longer.

Hi sapitts,
Thanks for the explanation. You are right about the delay for adaptivity . when I set the adaptivity  from interval = 6 to interval = 36, my simulations runs for very longer time.
Is there a way to define a fixed refined mesh at certain areas in the domain? I am not sure if the Pattern Mesh can do the trick.
Alireza
You could use initial adaptivity. I'm pretty sure that'll solve your issue here.

Take a look at this input file for example: https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/adaptivity/initial_adapt/initial_adapt.i . But as Stephanie said, incremental formulations in tensor mechanics with adaptivity are still under the works.
Thanks hungry, It helped a lot. Do you know how can I define multiple boxes instead of one?
Combo marker is for that exact purpose: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/markers/ComboMarker.html
Thank you , yep found it 10 min ago :)

node.title: help with compiling libmesh with boost
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am trying to compile the libMesh on hpc with an external boost, but I ran into some issues.
Basically, I have downloaded a boost (that is newer than the one in libMesh contrib), and the version.hpp is located at:
/hpc/group/dolbowlab/boost_1_75_0/boost/version.hpp.
However, when I try to compile libMesh using ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh --with-boost=/hpc/group/dolbowlab/boost_1_75_0 it says that it cannot find an external boost therefore falling back to the internal boost:
checking for boostlib >= 1.57.0... configure: We could not detect the boost libraries (version 1.57 or higher). If you have a staged boost library (still not installed) please specify $BOOST_ROOT in your environment and do not give a PATH to --with-boost option.  If you are sure you have boost installed, then check your version number looking in <boost/version.hpp>. See http://randspringer.de/boost for more documentation.
<<< External boost installation *not* found... will try to configure for libmesh's internal boost >>>

What am I missing here?
Thanks,
Gary
According to @roystgnr there doesn't seem to be an easy fix for this. I ended up manually including boost in my Makefile.

node.title: Weird transfer behavior for multiple source/target boundaries
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I'm hoping someone can help me figure out some strange behavior going on with the MultiAppNearestNodeTransfer when there are multiple source/target boundaries for the direction sub -> master. Let me describe the setup -
I have a 7-pin hexagonal bundle. For sake of demonstration, I've trimmed out all the physics to just focus on the transfer issue. The domains for the master app and sub app are identical, and in my application are coupled through boundary conditions on the clad surface (boundary ID 5) and duct inner surface (boundary ID 10). The transfers are as follows:
1: master -> sub: sends a temperature (nek_temp) from boundaries 5 and 10 in the master app to boundaries 5 and 10 in the sub app. This works just fine - the first picture below is nek_temp in the master app, while the second is nek_temp in the sub app after the transfer.
variable in master before transfer TO sub

variable in sub after transfer TO sub


sub -> master: sends a flux (avg_flux) from boundaries 5 and 10 in the sub app to boundaries 5 and 10 in the master app. I cannot seem to get this to work correctly if I use a source_boundary, which I want to do because my actual problems are really big, but the boundaries I'm passing data for are a relatively small part of the problem. Before I describe what I did, here's a visual of the avg_flux in the sub that I want to get sent to the master:

variable in sub before transfer FROM sub

Attempt 1: Try using source_boundary FROM sub
First, I obviously tried just using source_boundary for the data transfer for both the pins and duct. But, it seems that the second transfer in the input file (for the duct) overwrites whatever transfer I had just done for the pins. This picture shows that it looks like everywhere just takes the closest value based on the duct boundary. And, it doesn't even seem like I sent data just to one boundary in the master app, because every element has flux data.

Attempt 2: Try using source_boundary FROM sub, but switch the order
To confirm my hunch that using multiple source boundaries overwrites the first transfer, I switched the order of the pin and duct transfers, and it again seems like the duct flux in the master app is overwritten by the pin transfer based on an input file ordering. I definitely don't think there should be an order dependence-here, so this feels like a bug.

Attempt 3: Get rid of source_boundary FROM sub:
This seems to work correctly. But, I really want to use this feature because my problems are really big, and it should reduce the transfer time.

Questions

Is there a bug here? Why should the order of transfers matter (difference between attempts 1 and 2)?
Why does putting a source_boundary at all for sub->master seem to transfer data to the entire master domain?
How can I leverage the source_boundary feature from sub->master?

Here are all my input files.
example.zip

I figured this out in case anyone is interested!
If I change the variable I'm transferring in this example to a Lagrange variable, there's no strange transfer behavior. The issue is that target_boundary isn't used at all for elemental transfers, so because I was restricted to setting a single source/target boundary (because a vector is not yet implemented as an input option), I was basically overwriting the first transfer
source_boundary = '5'
target_boundary = '5' # not used, so this transfer was sending from boundary 5 to everywhere

with the second one
source_boundary = '10'
target_boundary = '10'  # not used, so this transfer was sending from boundary 10 to everywhere

I'm going to add an error if target_boundary is specified but you're transferring an elemental variable, because the transfer just doesn't make sense in that case, and you can run into unexpected behavior like I was seeing.

Hi. Yes I am. Someone advised me to use the "Adaptivity" block (It was off on in the original input file and in mine too); and it solved it. But I am not sure where the problem was exactly considering the original version worked well without it.
You may be running out of memory: Adaptivity can drastically increase the mesh, and everything else that goes with it.
Oh, okay, I see. I have a large memory so its not a problem for now I guess.

node.title: modeling a multi phase multi-shape initial condition
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE users,
I am trying to model a multi phase system (picture attached) that each phase has its own phase and concentration initial conditions. But I have a problem to model this IC. I could not use "SmoothSuperellipsoidIC" or the Circle one because I had already used "SubdomainBoundingBox" mesh modifier and it gave me the error of
***** ERROR ***
The initial condition 'c_fe_Oxide' is being defined on a block that already has an initial condition defined.**
Can any body help me please on     how can I implement this IC?
Best,
Alireza

Hi Alireza,
Could you quickly run your input file with the --mesh-only flag, load the result into paraview, and check that your subdomains (blocks) are actually as you desire?
a

Hi Andy,
I did that and it showed the 3 blocks as I had defined them in mesh modifier.  But no ellipsoid in the middle
A
So, if you need the 4th ellipsoidal block, you're going to have to use something like a ParsedSubdomainMeshModifier.  With 4 blocks, you can define an IC for each block separately.

I am looking in "https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/" and I could find  "ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator"  did you mean that?
If not, can you guide to where I can find "ParsedSubdomainMeshModifier" and some example input files of that?
Thanks,
A
Oh, i'm sorry, yes, i meant ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator

Hello again,
So, I followed your instruction to use "ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator" , (I have attached the part of code related to that) but I keep getting the error that:
*** ERROR ***
4eta_cirIC.i:2: section 'Mesh/gmc' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
4eta_cirIC.i:16: section 'Mesh/subdomains' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
I have tried different combination of  [ ] [ ] and  [./] [../] for the gmc and the subdomains part but still same error.
I was wondering if you could help on this.
Thanks,
Ali
4eta_cirIC.txt

It's almost right.  Use [./gmc] instead of [gmc].  Use [./subdomains] instead of [subdomains].  Also, remove the MeshModifiers and put them all in the [Mesh] block using a number of SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator.

I changed my input to:
[Mesh]
[./gmc]
type =  GeneratedMeshGenerator
dim = 2
nx = 100
ny = 100
xmax = 1000
xmin = 0
ymax = 1000
ymin = 0
elem_type = QUAD4
[]
[./subdomaincir]
type = ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator
input = gmc
combinatorial_geometry = '(x-400)^2+(y-500)^2<25'
block_id = 4
[]
[./Fe_bot]
  type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
  block_id = 1
  block_name = bot
  bottom_left = '0 0 0'
  top_right = '400 500 0'
[../]

[./Fe_top]
  type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
  block_id = 2
  block_name = up
  bottom_left = '0 500 0'
  top_right = '400 1000 0'
[../]

[./air]
  type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
  block_id = 3
  block_name = air
  bottom_left = '400 0 0 '
  top_right = '1000 1000 0'
[../]

[]
But I still get the same error!
*** ERROR ***
4eta_cirIC.i:2: section 'Mesh/gmc' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
4eta_cirIC.i:14: section 'Mesh/subdomaincir' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
4eta_cirIC.i:21: section 'Mesh/Fe_bot' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
4eta_cirIC.i:29: section 'Mesh/Fe_top' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?
4eta_cirIC.i:37: section 'Mesh/air' does not have an associated "Action".
Did you misspell it?

Hey,
Hopefully this helps...  This is my input file:
[Mesh]
[./gmc]
type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
dim = 2
nx = 100
ny = 100
xmax = 1000
xmin = 0
ymax = 1000
ymin = 0
elem_type = QUAD4
[]

[./Fe_bot]
  type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
  input = gmc
  block_id = 1
  block_name = bot
  bottom_left = '0 0 0'
  top_right = '400 500 0'
[../]

[./Fe_top]
  type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
  input = Fe_bot
  block_id = 2
  block_name = up
  bottom_left = '0 500 0'
  top_right = '400 1000 0'
[../]

[./air]
  type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
  input = Fe_top
  block_id = 3
  block_name = air
  bottom_left = '400 0 0 '
  top_right = '1000 1000 0'
[../]
[./subdomaincir]
type = ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator
input = air
  combinatorial_geometry = '((x-400)/0.5)^2+(y-500)^2<10000'
block_id = 4
[]


[]

I run it with this command:
myapp-opt -i tmp.i --mesh-only

and it produces this figure:

Thanks Andy,
I copy and pasted your input but it still shows the same error. Is this a new feature added to moose? since I have not updated the moose in last 12 months.
Best
Ali
Yes, that is almost definitely the problem.   You can continue with the old MOOSE but the above stuff won't work as i'm pretty sure the MeshGenerator stuff wasn't completed at that time.

node.title: A better way to export many "PointValue" to csv?
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE community
Here what I want to get from the output csv file are the time-changes of several variables at many selected points. For fewer points,  I can do this by repeatedly setting several "PointValue" in Postprocessors. However, if there are many points,  (e.g., 100),  the list becomes very long. Could anyone tell me is there a more convenient way for the purpose already designed in MOOSE?
ps: If I use VectorPostprocessors's PointValueSampler or LineValueSampler, there will be many csv files and lack time information. I want one csv file with time information.
Thank you!

For Vectorpostprocessors you can enable "time_data" in the CSV block to create an additional file that gives you the time information.
[Outputs]
  [out]
    type = CSV
    time_data = true
  []
[]

You can also output using the JSON format, which should give you the time information and only contain a single file. You will need to set the "vectorpostprocessors_as_reporters" option.
[Outputs]
  [out]
     type = JSON
    vectorpostprocessors_as_reporters = true
  []
[]

I third option would be to create a custom Reporter that allows you to list the points you want to report and store those in a vector. This would be a nice contribution for MOOSE. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Reporters/index.html

node.title: How to start a phase field fracture analysis?
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I'm new to MOOSE and want to do phase field fracture analysis, but I have no idea how to start and what should I do for now. I was wondering if there are any simple examples or tutorials to shed light on me. Any advice or comments will be highly appreciated.
Thanks,
RH

If you are looking for help specific to the phase field module, the main documentation page for that module might be a good place to start: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/index.html
If you want to work through a generic MOOSE tutorial and see other "getting started" resources, then I would go here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/index.html

Thanks @cticenhour .
I've learned the basic parts of MOOSE already, including the page you linked,and now I want to proceed to phase field fracture, wondering if there are any related examples.

Excellent - just wanted to make sure you had seen these since you said you were new to the framework! I'll let someone with experience in phase field continue the conversation. Perhaps @laagesen can chime in or recommend other resources?
Probably @jiangwen84 is the best person to highlight some PF fracture examples

We have a few regression tests located at moose/modules/combined/test/tests/phase_field_fracture/
The document of phase-field fracture is at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ComputeLinearElasticPFFractureStress.html
Thank you.
